packagegui.title: Services/BandwidthD

field.description: The interface where bandwidthd will listen for traffic.

The subnet(s) on which BandwidthD will collect statistics. Traffic that matches none of these subnets will be ignored.
Note: PPPoE interfaces are NOT supported!

Specify additional IPv4 subnet(s) in CIDR notation for statistics collection (or leave empty if none). For multiple subnets, separate entries with ';'
(Example: 192.168.1.0/24;10.0.0.0/24)
Note: Do NOT specify any local subnets already selected in 'Subnet(s) for Statistics Collection' above!
Put interface in promiscuous mode to see traffic that may not be routing through the host machine.
field.sethelp: Note: If the interface is connected to a switch then the interface will only see the traffic on its port.

Graph the traffic that BandwidthD is recording. Enabled by default.
field.sethelp:
Uncheck this to only generate CDF output or when using the database output option.
BandwidthD will use very little RAM and CPU when this option is disabled.

field.description:
Sets the interval, in seconds, at which the browser will refresh the graph display.
Default value is 150 seconds. A value of 0 will disable the refresh.

Number of intervals to skip between graphing.
Default 0. (Each interval is 200 seconds = 3 min 20 sec.)

Graph cutoff means how many KB must be transferred by an IP before it is graphed.
Default 1024.
Log data to CDF files log*.cdf
Read back the CDF files on startup.

If "Draw Graphs" is on, then the daily report and graph html data is regenerated every (skip intervals + 1) * 200 seconds.  The data volumes in the report are for the same period as the span of the graph.
If "Output to CDF" is on, then a cron job is added to rotate the log files at 00:01 each day. 6 log files are kept for each log frequency (daily, weekly, monthly, yearly).  At the respective rotation intervals, the oldest log is deleted, the others are shuffled back and a new log is created.

Libpcap format filter string used to control what traffic is counted.  Please, refer to pcap-filter(7) for documentation.
NOTE: You should always specify "ip" in the filter to avoid strange results.

Example: We only want to account for a certain IP.
Filter expression: ip and host 192.0.2.1

WARNING: You are completely on your own with this! If misconfigured, BandwidthD will malfunction or even not start at all.
